content: in the Top Gear Awards.

We go on a motoring holiday
with The Stig,

and Doctor Who travels
through space and time
a bit more slowly than usual.
Speed up!
Hello and welcome!
Thank you so much, thank you.

Wow! Now, we begin
with James May

who has found a car that seems
to make him rather cross.
This is the culprit.
The Jaguar S-Type.

This car really,
really winds me up.

It sums up everything
that's wrong with Jaguar.

You see, what they did with
the S-Type was to make a car

that they hoped would appeal
to Germans and Americans

and, you may ask,
what's wrong with that?
Well, quite a lot, actually.

You see, Mr Jonathan Foreigner has this
ridiculously outdated view of what Britain is.

He thinks we all live in
Anne Hathaway's cottage

and then go out
to ye olde tearooms

where we eat some
Kendal Mint Cake.

Then maybe we'll go out
and find a red phone box

and ring up some beefeaters
in the Tower of London,

to see if we can have
our bowler hats back.
It's rubbish!

And Jaguar absolutely pandered
to this view with the S-Type.

Just look at
that retro grille,
it's gawpingly awful.

Now, I've been banging on
about this for years.

And maybe, at last,
they've listened.

Because this is the
replacement for the S-Type...
...the Jaguar XF.

As soon as you
look at it you think,
"Ah, that's more like it."

You look at the new grille
and the subtly bulging bonnet
and the gills on the side.
Then there's the back,

which looks as though
it came from the XK.

Sounds like an XK as well.
You ready?

This is the first time
since I started this job

that I've been
in a Jaguar saloon

and felt that I was
in the right decade.

In Beverly Hills, your retired dentist,
he's going to have a heart attack

because,
"That's not proper Jaguar."
Well, so be it.

And there are more treats
on the inside.
Imagine you're a bank manager.

Now, in the olden days you'd
have climbed into your Jaguar,

checked your parting in your reflection
in the polished woodwork of your fascia,

and then you'd have
been on your way.
Now though...

The first thing
you notice is this

red starter button
pulsating like a heartbeat.

You touch that once
to turn the ignition on,

and you're immediately
bathed in this beautiful
pale blue light,

like something
from a funky vodka bar
and then, look at that!
Look at those opening.
Put your foot on the brake,

press it again
to start the engine...

...and this thing rises up
from the centre console.

That is actually
the gear change.

I know none of that
is strictly necessary,

but as you watch it
you can feel all those years

of financial drudgery
just falling away

until your 12 years old and
back in the world of Thunderbirds.

However, once you look past
all this futuristic garnish,

it's not quite so
Tomorrow's World.

Under the skin, the basic
structure is from the old S-Type,

and the suspension
is from the XK.

The engines are
also pretty old hat.

We've still got the V6 diesel,
the V6 petrol
and the V8 petrol,

with or without
the supercharger,

and they've been around
for donkey's years.

As Clarkson pointed out
when he drove the XK,

you get the sense that
Jaguar is pushing the limits
not of its technology
but of its overdraft.

But, if you were to keep
any old bits, it'd be these

because for a saloon,
this is superb.
It goes like a four-door XK.

It has the supercharger
on the 4.2-litre V8,

and it'll do nought to 60
in 5.1 seconds.

But interestingly this isn't the most
powerful version they're going to make.
There will be a Jaguar XFR,
with even more power.

And you can guess
who'll be driving that one.
If I have one criticism,

it's that the ride
in this SV8 version

is harder than you'd
expect from a Jaguar.

But it still wipes the floor
with the Audi A6.

And when it comes to
value for money,

it duffs up
the BMW 5 Series too.

Every model in the range
comes with leather,

the excellent paddle-shift
automatic gearbox,

touch-screen Sat Nav,
electric seats, decent alloys
and "Blueteeth".

For years the sleek and modern
Germans were having it easy,

because all we had to take
them on was Cholmondley-Warner.
Now though, we have this.

Make no mistake,
the XF is very good,
but more than that,

it means Jaguar
has finally found the balls

to make a saloon that
belongs in the present.

It is a good looking car,
it is really good looking.

- So you like this because it's modern and contemporary?
- Yes, like me.

If you're modern and contemporary,
why do you spit out the word "German"

every time you say it in any film, like
it's 1941 and the sky's full of Heinkels?

- I don't, do I?
- You do! Every time you say "GERMAN".
I like the GERMANS.

- Shall we do The News?
- Yes.

Right, the news, and did you know
James has won an award?

He has, he's officially Heat Magazine's
Weird Crush of the Year!
No!

There's actually been another award this
week, you two don't know about this one.

Brylcreem have made awards for
the best celebrity hairstyle on television!

- Oh go on.
- 3rd place, Alex Zane.

2nd place, Steve Jones, who was
in the Sex Pistols as far as I know,

and the winner, the best
celebrity hairstyle on television...
Richard Hammond!

- I haven't got a hairstyle!
- What!?

- I haven't, it's just some hair!
- You don't have that styled?

- No, it just happened!
- We're 20 minutes late starting the show

'cause the makeup girl's been out 40 times!
They've also done worst the celebrity hair.

- Third place... Rhydian?
- No idea.
X-what? X-FACTAH!

Second place is Simon Cowell,
also X-Factor. And the winner...
The worst haircut on television...

- James May!
- Oh no!

So that makes you a double award winner?
It's official, you're weird with bad hair!

Shocking hair. Uh, right, now the Morgan
AeroMax, the car Richard's just bought,

got a picture of it here, okay?
They're making 100 of those, right?

- Very rare.
- Okay. Now you'd imagine the other 99 buying them are "real men"

in tweed jackets, who go down to the pub
for a pint of Best with twigs in it and mud

- and leaves.
- Yes.

- So you wanna guess who ordered one of those this week?
- Kenneth Moore.

- No.
- Edward Fox?
No. Paul O'Grady!

You'll be able to go for weekends
in the country together with your Morgans!

- That's an exclusive club.
- Uh, now it's time to talk about cars.

Specifically cars that are coming out in
2008, next year. The best car, by a mile,

is this. This is the Alfa Romeo 8C.
I am nursing a semi just looking at it.

- You've kind of spoiled it.
- £110,000. Carbon fibre, rear wheel drive,

every single thing about it, I want.
And it's an Alfa, you know.

Car I'm really looking forward to,
the new Koenigsegg CCX... R.

Ooh aah, yes exactly. Underneath all the
sleek carbon fibre bodywork is a V8,

- two superchargers, and it's putting out 1000bhp. 250mph.
- Is it green?

The clever thing is it runs on biofuel, so
technically that's a green car right there!

- We could buy Al Gore one! How much is it?
- Oh yes, it is quite costly.

Uh, ooh now, hey, if you're watching this
as a repeat, it's Christmas Day,

So Happy Christmas! If however you're
watching it on Sunday, you've got one

shopping day left 'til Christmas, so we
thought we'd give you some gift ideas.

And we're gonna begin, if I may, with this.
It's down here, it's a "TravelRabbit".

No no, I think... obviously what you do is
you plug it into the cigarette lighter

and then this little chap "vibrates" and
jiggles about to amuse the passengers.

- That's smashing!
- I think that's rather nice.

- That's a lovely gift.
- That's a Christmas novelty, rather nice.

Have you ever thought
"Oh no, my shoehorn is far too heavy!"

- Yes. Every single-well I haven't got one.
- Well, help is at hand with this

special, lightweight,
carbon fibre-ended shoehorn!

- They put carbon fibre on a shoehorn? It's very light.
- It is.

That's the stupidest thing I've ever seen!
You could put that in your dungeon, James.

- Here's a great one for you... this. Bugatti aftershave. Ah.
- Mmm.

- It's... well guess how much.
- Well it's Bugatti...

- Sixty quid?
- No, it's Bugatti!

- 150 quid?
- 1500 quid!

- What!?
- What is it?

- It's...
- Does this make Richard more attractive?

- Careful with your hairstyle.
- It's quite nice. Is anybody getting it?

- Is anybody getting...?
- Give me some then.

- I want to go home smelling like a Bugatti.
- Tell you something else, they lent it!
He just spent 400 quid!
Do you like it?

Do you want some? Here, put some on.
You'll be able to lose your virginity then.

Happy Christmas, what a gift!
What a gift he got you!

Get it in there! You'll never smell as good
again! What does it smell of, exactly?

Well, it's an original fragrance, shrouded
in mystery with underlying notes of

cedar wood and Vettiver. They say it's
"timelessly elegant."

- Excellent.
- It is, because there's more for £1500.

'Cause you get this. Look, see, it's like a
sculpture and it comes with this handy

carbon fibre carrying case that you put it
in... so, no, as you go through your day,

it's light so you can carry it around, and
when you need it, you can deploy it.

Get it out, and away you go.
That's £1000 to spray your armpits.

- It's quite strong.
- It is quite strong.

Lost your virginity yet? Do you want
some more? He's gone really red now.

That means there's no blood
left to go anywhere else.

Right, now we've got to
get on with The News.

If you're 8, here's a question: If it snows
this Christmas, would you like a red,

moulded, high-tech, plastic,
very fast Ferrari sledge for £50?

Or, for a little bit more, would you prefer
this wooden one with Nissan written on it?

Actually, Nissan have a number of branded
products out for Christmas this year.

They've gone bonkers with it. I've been
through the catalogue, so,

for instance, here it is. Big day arrives,
you go scampering downstairs, has he been?

"He has, this is for me!" I guarantee you
won't guess. This is yours for Christmas.

Because here it is... a wobbly-headed model
of the former President of Nissan USA!

- You are joking!
- His head wobbles, look!

- I don't care!
- No look, it says on the back.
"The father of the Z-Car... no!"

You've just pulled the wobbly head off the
former President of Nissan USA!

- Nobody's ever said that before.
- No, I don't suppose they have.

- Now look what's happened!
- You've ruined it!

Wait... everybody. There is another
Nissan present. I'm gonna go and get it.

- What?
- No no, I am gonna go and get it.

I am gonna go and get it. I wasn't gonna
treat you but I'm gonna treat you all.

It's not a beheaded former President of
Nissan USA? They have gone mad though,

- I went to the catalogue, they've done the Nissan barstool, very stylish.
- What?

Better still, in the catalogue
there is a Nissan guitar. What?
Whoa there! Whoa!

- That's quite strong!
- The Nissan Z-Car shirt.

- Hang on, Jeremy. Have a squirt of that.
- What?

- Yep.
- You're getting ready for Christmas.

Oh yeah. I've got everything I need. I've
got a TravelRabbit, aftershave and a shirt.

And you've-
And I've got my headless businessman.

- I'm ready.
- No you're not, because what you need

- for your tree are some Lamborghini baubles.
- Perfect. Christmas is here!

- Bet that gets cut up.
- I bet it does as well!

Which is a good thing, because I need to
take those home because I quite like them.
Okey doke.

- Aw, bollocks! Sorry, I dropped it.
- Sorry, I dropped it as well.
Lamborghini bauble?

- Happy Christmas!
- It's like The Who!

Happy Christmas, everybody!
Marley was dead!
Everything's ruined!

If this is how your Christmas Day went,
sorry. That was a proper Christmas Day,

I think, everything's broken.
Right,

The BMW M3 is the world's
best-selling performance car.
And is driven exclusively by cocks.

- That doesn't matter.
- No, It does, honestly,

because every
single one of them

talks about marketing
and solutions and paradigm.

And they've all got those
ridiculous mobile phone earpieces in.
Yeah, he's right.

The point is
there's a new one out.

To see if it's any good,
I took it to Spain

to The Stig's favourite
holiday resort.

Behind tough security,
to keep out the riffraff,

there are pleasant gardens
where he can relax,
a pool where he can unwind,

and in the evening
a top-notch restaurant,
where he can gorge on meat.

It's a lovely spot
with excellent views,
and, oh, yes, nearly forgot.
In the grounds,

there's a five and a half
kilometre race track.

It was built as a plaything
by a Dutch oil billionaire

and features copies of some
of the best corners

from other race tracks
around the world.
It is a fantastic place.

But the car I'm driving
is even better.

The last M3 had a
straight-six engine.
This has a four-litre V8.
But don't think for a minute

it's become a big,
lazy muscle car.

Yes, it's a big V8,
but it revs at 8,300 rpm.
It's such a screamer.

That said, it is softer
than the old car.
And more forgiving,

but it's also noticeably
faster and cleverer.

You can actually change
the feel of the car

and the performance on the
iDrive control system.

Meanwhile the M differential
gets busy at the back

to keep the power going
to exactly the right place
at exactly the right time.

Sometimes it will even lock
the rear wheels together,

so you can pull
spectacular tail slides.

Even if your fists
are made of ham.
I love this car.
Get out of the way!

- That'll be Jeremy then.
- Here I come.

This is Mercedes'
answer to the M3.

It's the AMG C-Class
and it's not a car,
it's a complete animal.
Oh! Cripes!

You don't really drive this
car, you cling on for dear life!

Sure, the new M3 has a top-notch
conventional weapon under the bonnet
but this, this has a nuke.
It's a 6.2 litre V8.

It's not the full-fat 6.2
they put in their bigger cars.

But even this
semi-skimmed version
has 450 brake horsepower.

So the 'umph' is as phenomenal
as the noise it makes.
Listen to that!

It's not only louder,
more powerful
and more exciting than the M3,
but it's simpler as well.

It even has
an automatic gear box.

I will admit, however, that
there are one or two things
I'm not sure about.
It's not a very pretty car.

I don't like the way Merc has
copied BMW's iDrive system,

their old control centre was
better, it was easier to use.

And then,
rising above all this,
is the problem
with the traction control.

When it's on,
it's constantly interfering,

every time you go
near the throttle.

Eventually, of course, you
become impatient and turn it off.

But be advised,
if you do that,
you'd better be awake.
Oops-a-daisy.

I've got it. There we are...
Oh, dear. No.

This is just an axe murderer
with headlights.
And I absolutely adore it.
This is mental.

Jeremy, there's more to life

I'm sorry, but the whole

I'm sorry,

your sparkly

Tell me you like the chrome.

It's an Audi RS4.
